title: The Water Cycle
image_desc: A diagram showing the water cycle with arrows indicating the movement of water from the ocean to the atmosphere, to the land, and back to the ocean.
content: - The water cycle describes the continuous movement of water on, above and below the surface of the Earth.
It is a natural process that is essential for all life on Earth.
narration: The water cycle is like a giant, never-ending journey for water. It starts in the ocean, where water evaporates into the air. This water vapor then condenses into clouds, and eventually falls back to Earth as rain, snow, or hail. The water then flows back to the ocean, completing the cycle.

title: Evaporation
image_desc: A picture of a lake with steam rising from the surface.
content: - Evaporation is the process of water changing from a liquid to a gas.
This happens when the sun heats up water, causing it to evaporate into the air.
narration: Imagine a sunny day at the beach. The sun warms the water, and you can see tiny droplets of water rising into the air. This is evaporation! The heat from the sun gives the water molecules enough energy to escape from the liquid and become water vapor.

title: Condensation
image_desc: A picture of fluffy white clouds in the sky.
content: - Condensation is the process of water vapor changing from a gas to a liquid.
This happens when water vapor in the air cools down and forms clouds.
narration: As the water vapor rises higher in the atmosphere, it gets colder. This causes the water vapor to cool down and condense back into tiny water droplets. These droplets clump together to form clouds, which we see in the sky.

title: Precipitation
image_desc: A picture of a rainstorm with heavy rain falling.
content: - Precipitation is any form of water that falls from the atmosphere to the Earth's surface.
This includes rain, snow, sleet, and hail.
narration: When the water droplets in clouds become too heavy, they fall back to Earth as precipitation. This can be rain, snow, sleet, or hail, depending on the temperature of the air.

title: Collection
image_desc: A picture of a river flowing into the ocean.
content: - Collection is the process of water gathering in bodies of water, such as oceans, lakes, and rivers.
This water can then evaporate again, starting the cycle over.
narration: After precipitation falls to the Earth, it flows into rivers, lakes, and oceans. This water is then ready to evaporate again, starting the water cycle all over again. It's a continuous process that keeps our planet alive and healthy.
